entry.et: Middle English solempne, from Anglo-French, from Latin sollemnis regularly appointed, solemn

def.dt: :marked by the invocation of a religious sanction a solemn oath
:marked by the observance of established form or ceremony
:marked by grave sedateness and earnest sobriety a solemn gathering
:a mass marked by the use of incense and by the presence of a deacon and a subdeacon in attendance on the celebrant
:an absolute and irrevocable public vow taken by a religious in the Roman Catholic Church under which ownership of property by the individual is prohibited and marriage is invalid under canon law
